title: Example Analysis
text: table_codes “om7013rr” “om7005rr”. dimension parameters must supplied order appear example href table. om7013rr 3 dimension parameters order: om7013rr_vuc: regional codes, supply vector om7013rr_obd: “” years om7013rr_ukaz: “IN010052” permanently living mid-year population om7013rr_poh: c(“1”, “2”) sex om7005rr 4 dimension parameters order: om7005rr_vuc: regional codes, supply vector om7005rr_obd: “” years om7005rr_ukaz: “IN010089” mean age om7005rr_poh: c(“1”, “2”) sex Since interested 79 districts, firstly retrieve dimension values use vector values feed fetch_susr_data() function. codes tables, .
code: districts <- susr_dimension_values("om7013rr",                                    "om7013rr_vuc") |>    filter(str_detect(element_label, "District of"))   params <- list(   "om7013rr", # 1st table   list( # list of params for 1st table     districts$element_value, # vector of district codes      "all",                   # all years     "IN010052",               # population     c("1", "2")              # sex: 1 = M, 2 = F          ),   "om7005rr", # 2nd table   list( # list of params for 2nd table     districts$element_value, # vector of district codes      "all",                   # all years     "IN010089",              # mean age     c("1", "2")              # sex: 1 = M, 2 = F     ) )

title: Example Analysis
text: Let’s inspect data: already see, quite differences regions population mean age.
code: res <- fetch_susr_data(params)  # res is a named list with two entries pop_df <- res[["om7013rr"]] age_df <- res[["om7005rr"]] summary(pop_df) #>  om7013rr_vuc       om7013rr_obd       om7013rr_ukaz      om7013rr_poh       #>  Length:4424        Length:4424        Length:4424        Length:4424        #>  Class :character   Class :character   Class :character   Class :character   #>  Mode  :character   Mode  :character   Mode  :character   Mode  :character   #>                                                                              #>                                                                              #>                                                                              #>  om7013rr_data          value       #>  Length:4424        Min.   : 5338   #>  Class :character   1st Qu.:19797   #>  Mode  :character   Median :30844   #>                     Mean   :34242   #>                     3rd Qu.:47132   #>                     Max.   :90029 summary(age_df) #>  om7005rr_vuc       om7005rr_obd       om7005rr_ukaz      om7005rr_poh       #>  Length:4424        Length:4424        Length:4424        Length:4424        #>  Class :character   Class :character   Class :character   Class :character   #>  Mode  :character   Mode  :character   Mode  :character   Mode  :character   #>                                                                              #>                                                                              #>                                                                              #>  om7005rr_data          value       #>  Length:4424        Min.   :28.19   #>  Class :character   1st Qu.:36.09   #>  Mode  :character   Median :38.58   #>                     Mean   :38.52   #>                     3rd Qu.:40.95   #>                     Max.   :46.84

title: Example Analysis
text: adjust raw data user-friendly follow common conventions. Afterwards merge tables one.
code: cleaned_pop_df <- pop_df |>    rename( # renaming to more user-friendly names     district = om7013rr_vuc,     year  = om7013rr_obd,     population  = value,     sex = om7013rr_poh   ) |>    mutate(sex = ifelse(sex == "Men", 0, 1)) |> # refactoring sex   select(district, year, sex, population)   cleaned_age_df <- age_df |>    rename( # renaming to more user-friendly names     district = om7005rr_vuc,     year  = om7005rr_obd,     mean_age  = value,     sex = om7005rr_poh   ) |>    mutate(sex = ifelse(sex == "Men", 0, 1)) |> # refactoring sex   select(district, year, sex, mean_age)  merged_df <- cleaned_pop_df |>    left_join(cleaned_age_df, by = join_by(district, year, sex), keep = FALSE)

title: Example Analysis
text: can see, district age getting older. However couple flat-ish ones disrupting pattern. animated chart can see districts different “movement” time. Especially district Senec moves lower deciles mean age - meaning ageing slower districts. fact seems like mean age stable last 20 years.
code: ggplot(merged_df |> filter(sex == 1), aes(x = year, y = mean_age, group = district, color = district)) +   geom_line() +   labs(title = "Mean Age Trend Over Years - Females", x = "Year", y = "Mean Age") +   theme_minimal() +   guides(color = "none") ggplot(merged_df |> filter(sex == 0), aes(x = year, y = mean_age, group = district, color = district)) +   geom_line() +   labs(title = "Mean Age Trend Over Years - Males", x = "Year", y = "Mean Age") +   theme_minimal() +   guides(color = "none") # Calculate population per district per year data_bubble <- merged_df |>    reframe(     .by = c(district, year),     tot_population = sum(population),     mean_age = round(sum(mean_age * population) / tot_population, 1)   ) |>     group_by(year) |>    mutate(     age_decile = ntile(mean_age, 10)  # Divide districts into deciles by mean age   ) |>    ungroup()     # Animated interactive bubble chart bubble_chart <- plot_ly(   data_bubble,   x = ~tot_population,   y = ~mean_age,   size = ~tot_population,   sizes = c(10, 250),   color = ~age_decile,   frame = ~year,   text = ~district,   type = 'scatter',   mode = 'markers' ) %>%   layout(     title = "Change over Time",     xaxis = list(title = "Total Population"),     yaxis = list(title = "Mean Age"),     showlegend = FALSE   ) |>    colorbar(title = "Age decile")  bubble_chart

title: Getting started with susR
text: susR provides R interface Slovak Statistical Office (SUSR) open data API, making easier : List available tables (dimension codes). Retrieve metadata tables (e.g., domain, subdomain). Fetch data JSON-stat format. Convert data user-friendly tibbles ready analysis. vignette guides basic workflow: installing susR fetching data. Installation haven’t already installed susR, can GitHub: load :
code: devtools::install_github("Arnold-Kakas/susR") library(susR)

title: Getting started with susR
text: two options retrieve available tables. First calling susr_domains() functions reads saved list available tables, names, domain subdomains: Second call SUSR API: returns tibble columns like table_code, href, dimension_names, label, update. want certain domains subdomains, can passing one () domains /subdomains susr_domains() result: can pass parameter long = TRUE order fetch data long format row contain one dimension.
code: susr_domains_table <- susr_domains() head(susr_domains_table) #> # A tibble: 6 × 4 #>   table_code table_name                                         domain subdomain #>   <chr>      <chr>                                              <chr>  <chr>     #> 1 as1001rs   Population and attributes of age                   Indic… Indicato… #> 2 as1002rs   Participation of seniors in the labour market      Indic… Indicato… #> 3 as1003rs   Net money income and expenditure of households by… Indic… Indicato… #> 4 as1004rs   Expenditure of households on selected goods and s… Indic… Indicato… #> 5 as1005rs   At-risk-of-poverty rate by selected age group and… Indic… Indicato… #> 6 as1006rs   Social and pension security                        Indic… Indicato… susr_tables <- susr_tables() head(susr_tables) #> # A tibble: 6 × 6 #>   class   href                           table_code label update dimension_names #>   <chr>   <chr>                          <chr>      <chr> <chr>  <chr>           #> 1 dataset https://data.statistics.sk/ap… as1001rs   Popu… 2024-… as1001rs_rok:a… #> 2 dataset https://data.statistics.sk/ap… as1002rs   Part… 2024-… as1002rs_rok:a… #> 3 dataset https://data.statistics.sk/ap… as1003rs   Net … 2024-… as1003rs_rok:a… #> 4 dataset https://data.statistics.sk/ap… as1004rs   Expe… 2024-… as1004rs_rok:a… #> 5 dataset https://data.statistics.sk/ap… as1005rs   At-r… 2024-… as1005rs_rok:a… #> 6 dataset https://data.statistics.sk/ap… as1006rs   Soci… 2024-… as1006rs_rok:a… # Example: filter by domain = "Demographic and social statistics" domain_tables <- susr_tables(domain = "Demographic and social statistics")  dim(domain_tables) #> [1] 231   9 subdomain_tables <- susr_tables(domain = "Housing")  dim(subdomain_tables) #> [1] 2 9 multiple_subdomain_tables <- susr_tables(domain = c("Housing", "Energy"))  dim(multiple_subdomain_tables) #> [1] 12  9 subdomain_tables_long <- susr_tables(domain = "Housing",                                      long = TRUE)  dim(subdomain_tables_long) #> [1] 10  8

title: Getting started with susR
text: can see valid dimension values using susr_dimension_values(). can map function susr_tables() output long format.
code: dims <- susr_dimension_values(table_code = "bv3001rr",                               dimension_code = "bv3001rr_voda")  dims #> # A tibble: 4 × 6 #>   dimension_code dimension_label dimension_note element_index element_value #>   <chr>          <chr>           <chr>                  <int> <chr>         #> 1 bv3001rr_voda  bv3001rr_voda   Water supply               0 VODATOT       #> 2 bv3001rr_voda  bv3001rr_voda   Water supply               1 VODA01        #> 3 bv3001rr_voda  bv3001rr_voda   Water supply               2 VODA02        #> 4 bv3001rr_voda  bv3001rr_voda   Water supply               3 VODA03        #> # ℹ 1 more variable: element_label <chr> library(dplyr) #>  #> Attaching package: 'dplyr' #> The following objects are masked from 'package:stats': #>  #>     filter, lag #> The following objects are masked from 'package:base': #>  #>     intersect, setdiff, setequal, union library(purrr) library(tidyr)  # 1) Get all tables in the "Energy" domain, in long format energy_long <- susr_tables(domain = "Energy", long = TRUE)  # Inspect the columns: # - table_code # - dimension_code # - plus other metadata (domain, subdomain, label, href, etc.)  # 2) Map susr_dimension_values() across each row: #    We'll create a new list-column 'dim_info' that stores the dimension values energy_long_dim <- energy_long |>    mutate(     dim_info = map2(table_code, dimension_code, ~ susr_dimension_values(.x, .y))   )  # Now `energy_long_dim$dim_info` is a list of tibbles/data frames (one for each dimension). # Each entry holds columns like: #   dimension_code, dimension_label, dimension_note, element_code, element_label, etc.  # 3) (Optional) Unnest into a single combined data frame #    If you'd like a tall data frame where each row is a unique dimension element: full_dim_info <- energy_long_dim |>    unnest(cols = dim_info, names_sep = "dim_")  # `full_dim_info` now contains columns: #   class, href, table_code, label, update, dimension_code,  #   (optionally) domain/subdomain,  #   and the un-nested dimension columns from susr_dimension_values().  head(full_dim_info) #> # A tibble: 6 × 14 #>   class   href           table_code label update dimension_code domain subdomain #>   <chr>   <chr>          <chr>      <chr> <chr>  <chr>          <chr>  <chr>     #> 1 dataset https://data.… en1001ms   Sour… 2024-… en1001ms_rok   Multi… Energy    #> 2 dataset https://data.… en1001ms   Sour… 2024-… en1001ms_rok   Multi… Energy    #> 3 dataset https://data.… en1001ms   Sour… 2024-… en1001ms_rok   Multi… Energy    #> 4 dataset https://data.… en1001ms   Sour… 2024-… en1001ms_rok   Multi… Energy    #> 5 dataset https://data.… en1001ms   Sour… 2024-… en1001ms_rok   Multi… Energy    #> 6 dataset https://data.… en1001ms   Sour… 2024-… en1001ms_rok   Multi… Energy    #> # ℹ 6 more variables: dim_infodim_dimension_code <chr>, #> #   dim_infodim_dimension_label <chr>, dim_infodim_dimension_note <chr>, #> #   dim_infodim_element_index <int>, dim_infodim_element_value <chr>, #> #   dim_infodim_element_label <chr>

title: Getting started with susR
text: know table code dimension segments, use fetch_susr_data(). want fetch data multiple tables multiple pairs table codes dimension lists: element multi_res tibble given table code.
code: params <- list(   "np3106rr",   list("SK021", c("2016","2017","2018"), "E_PRIEM_HR_MZDA", "all"),   "as1001rs",   list("all", "all", "all") )  multi_res <- fetch_susr_data(params)  names(multi_res) #> [1] "np3106rr" "as1001rs"  class(multi_res$np3106rr) #> [1] "tbl_df"     "tbl"        "data.frame"

title: Getting started with susR
text: data, use dplyr ggplot2 (anything else) analyze:
code: library(ggplot2)  p <- multi_res$as1001rs |>   filter(as1001rs_ukaz == "Pre-productive population (aged 0 -14 years)",          as1001rs_poh == "Total") |>   ggplot() +   geom_line(aes(x = as1001rs_rok, y = value, group = 1)) +   labs(title = "Pre-productive population (aged 0 -14 years)",        x = "Year",        y = NULL) +   theme_minimal()   p

title: Authors and Citation
text: Arnold Kakas. Author, maintainer.

title: Authors and Citation
text: Kakas (2025). susR: Interface Accessing Open Data Slovak Statistical Office via API. R package version 0.0.0.9000, https://arnold-kakas.github.io/susR/.
code: @Manual{,   title = {susR: Interface for Accessing the Open Data of Slovak Statistical Office via API},   author = {Arnold Kakas},   year = {2025},   note = {R package version 0.0.0.9000},   url = {https://arnold-kakas.github.io/susR/}, }

what: Interface for Accessing the Open Data of Slovak Statistical Office via API
title: Interface for Accessing the Open Data of Slovak Statistical Office via API
text: susR R package providing convenient interface Slovak Statistical Office (SUSR) open data API. simplifies tasks : Listing available tables. Retrieving dimension codes values selected table(s). Fetching data straightforward manner. Returning user-friendly tibbles ready analysis. allows explore official Slovak statistical data directly within R, ensuring reproducible efficient workflow.

title: Interface for Accessing the Open Data of Slovak Statistical Office via API
text: can install development version susR GitHub :
code: devtools::install_github("Arnold-Kakas/susR")

title: Interface for Accessing the Open Data of Slovak Statistical Office via API
text: basic example illustrating might use susR list available tables fetch dimension values specific one. details additional functions, usage examples, retrieve actual data, check package documentation view vignette. bugs feature requests, please open issue GitHub repo. Happy analyzing susR!
code: library(susR)  # 1) Retrieve a list of all available tables tables <- susr_tables()  head(tables) #> # A tibble: ...  #> #   class   href                                            table_code ... #> #   <chr>   <chr>                                           <chr>      ... #> #   ...  # 2) Suppose we want the dimension values for the first table's first dimension: #    We'll pick a table code and a dimension code from the table info  table_code <- tables$table_code[1] # E.g., "as1001rs" or something similar dimension_code <- "as1001rs_rok" # Hypothetical dimension code  dim_values <- susr_dimension_values(table_code, dimension_code)  head(dim_values) #> # A tibble: ... #> #   dimension_code  dimension_label dimension_note element_index element_value element_label #> #   ...

what: Retrieve data from SUSR (Slovak Statistical Office) open data API as data frames — fetch_susr_data
title: Retrieve data from SUSR (Slovak Statistical Office) open data API as data frames — fetch_susr_data
text: function constructs calls dataset endpoint one tables, including dimension selections, returns data frame (tibble). Internally, fetches JSON-stat parses using rjstat package.

title: Retrieve data from SUSR (Slovak Statistical Office) open data API as data frames — fetch_susr_data
code: fetch_susr_data(   params,   lang = "en",   base_url = "https://data.statistics.sk/api/v2/dataset" )

title: Retrieve data from SUSR (Slovak Statistical Office) open data API as data frames — fetch_susr_data
text: params list structured pairs: character string table code (e.g. "np3106rr"). list (vector) dimension "segments" order appear URL. segment can : character scalar (e.g. "SK021"), character vector (e.g. c("2016","2017","2018")) join commas ("2016,2017,2018"), Special keywords like "", "last5", etc. (passed -). multiple tables, just keep repeating pairs list. lang language code. Defaults "en". Can also "sk". base_url base SUSR dataset endpoint. Defaults "https://data.statistics.sk/api/v2/dataset".

title: Retrieve data from SUSR (Slovak Statistical Office) open data API as data frames — fetch_susr_data
text: named list data frames, keyed table codes. request data two tables (e.g. "np3106rr" "as1001rs"), get list two tibbles. example:
code: $np3106rr       # A tibble with columns for the dimension categories and the measured value      $as1001rs       # Another tibble for that table

title: Retrieve data from SUSR (Slovak Statistical Office) open data API as data frames — fetch_susr_data
text: order dimension segments crucial. example, official URL pattern : pass list("param1", "param2", "param3") exact order. Internally, JSON-stat response converted data frame (tibble) using rjstat::fromJSONstat(). JSON structure invalid API call fails, store NULL emit warning table.
code: https://data.statistics.sk/api/v2/dataset/<table_code>/<param1>/<param2>/<param3>?lang=en&type=json

title: Retrieve data from SUSR (Slovak Statistical Office) open data API as data frames — fetch_susr_data
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # Example: retrieve data from two tables params <- list(   "np3106rr",   list("SK021", c("2016","2017","2018"), "E_PRIEM_HR_MZDA", "7"),   "as1001rs",   list("all", "all", "all")  # e.g. get all years, all other dims )  res <- fetch_susr_data(params, lang = "en") names(res) #> [1] "np3106rr" "as1001rs"  # Each element is a data frame. For example: head(res[["np3106rr"]]) } # }

what: Retrieve all possible values for a specific dimension in a given table — susr_dimension_values
title: Retrieve all possible values for a specific dimension in a given table — susr_dimension_values
text: function queries dimension endpoint: https://data.statistics.sk/api/v2/dimension/<table_code>/<dimension_code>?lang=<lang> given table code dimension code, returning tibble possible values (element codes labels) dimension.

title: Retrieve all possible values for a specific dimension in a given table — susr_dimension_values
code: susr_dimension_values(table_code, dimension_code, lang = "en")

title: Retrieve all possible values for a specific dimension in a given table — susr_dimension_values
text: table_code string table code (e.g. "as1001rs"). 8-character (similar) code identifying data cube. dimension_code string dimension code (e.g. "as1001rs_rok"). lang string specifying language code, either "en" "sk". Defaults "en".

title: Retrieve all possible values for a specific dimension in a given table — susr_dimension_values
text: tibble columns: dimension_code provided dimension code (e.g. "as1001rs_rok") dimension_label short label dimension (available) dimension_note descriptive note dimension (available) element_index Index element. element_value possible value code (e.g. "2016", "SK021", etc.) element_label descriptive label element code (available).

title: Retrieve all possible values for a specific dimension in a given table — susr_dimension_values
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # For table code "as1001rs" and dimension "as1001rs_rok": dim_vals <- susr_dimension_values("as1001rs", "as1001rs_rok") head(dim_vals) } # }

what: Load manual table list (with domain & subdomain) from CSV — susr_domains
title: Load manual table list (with domain & subdomain) from CSV — susr_domains
text: function reads static CSV file containing manual list tables along domain subdomain information.

title: Load manual table list (with domain & subdomain) from CSV — susr_domains
code: susr_domains()

title: Load manual table list (with domain & subdomain) from CSV — susr_domains
text: tibble (data frame) columns like: table_code domain subdomain ... (others may )

title: Load manual table list (with domain & subdomain) from CSV — susr_domains
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{   df <- susr_domains()   head(df) } # }

what: Get the list of all available datasets (tables) from the Slovak Statistical Office — susr_tables
title: Get the list of all available datasets (tables) from the Slovak Statistical Office — susr_tables
text: function calls SUSR open data API endpoint https://data.statistics.sk/api/v2/collection?lang=en obtain list datasets, optionally filters domain/subdomain /table code, returns results tibble.

title: Get the list of all available datasets (tables) from the Slovak Statistical Office — susr_tables
code: susr_tables(long = FALSE, domains = NULL, table_codes = NULL)

title: Get the list of all available datasets (tables) from the Slovak Statistical Office — susr_tables
text: long Logical (default FALSE). TRUE, result "long" one row per dimension code (see Details). domains Character vector NULL (default). provided, filter tables whose domain subdomain matches values. Domain info taken static CSV loaded via susr_domains(). table_codes Character vector NULL (default). provided, filter table codes.

title: Get the list of all available datasets (tables) from the Slovak Statistical Office — susr_tables
text: tibble. columns differ slightly depending long (wide vs. long). Always contains: class, href, table_code, label, update long = FALSE: also dimension_names long = TRUE: also dimension_code domain used, columns domain / subdomain susr_domains() also included.

title: Get the list of all available datasets (tables) from the Slovak Statistical Office — susr_tables
text: long = FALSE (default), row corresponds single dataset dimension codes concatenated dimension_names column, separated ":". long = TRUE, function pivots dimension code row (dimension_code). domains NULL, function calls susr_domains() retrieve static CSV domain subdomain data, joins table_code, filters accordingly. table_codes NULL, filter final list codes.

title: Get the list of all available datasets (tables) from the Slovak Statistical Office — susr_tables
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # 1) Get all tables (wide format, no filtering) tables_all <- susr_tables()  # 2) Filter to just certain table codes: tables_some <- susr_tables(table_code = c("as1001rs", "as1002rs"))  # 3) Filter by domain or subdomain: #    e.g., if your CSV has domain = "Environment", "Macroeconomic statistics", etc. env_tables <- susr_tables(domain = "Environment")  # 4) Combined: filter by domain + get long format macroeconomic_tables <- susr_tables(long = TRUE, domain = "Macroeconomic statistics") } # }

title: susR 0.0.1
text: first release version susR! 🎉 Added NEWS.md file track changes package. susr_domains() susr_tables() susr_dimension_values() fetch_susr_data() Getting started susR Example Analysis
